post_info.post_title: God doesn't sound like "intelligent" design to me...

Liminus

Believe me, you aren't the first.
 
 If anyone replies to you, you won't be given any facts. You'll be given:
 
 1) Uniformed, misrepresentative reaons as to why evolution isn't believable.
 
 2) Ridiculous, unverifiable 'proofs' of God's existence.
 
 3) Quotes from the bible.
THE_oldy

You can only prove some thing in relation to the laws of physics, and because creation blindly ignores the laws of physics you can prove it. More about this in my "Differences of science and religion" thread.
pandion

You can only prove some thing in relation to the laws of physics,...
Actually not true. Science, physics or otherwise, doesn't prove anything. Science explains with tested theories. That's what scientific theories are; explanations that account for all (hopefully) the known facts. Uncover more facts and perhaps the theory (your proof) will have to be changed to account for them.
 
...and because creation blindly ignores the laws of physics you can prove it.
I presume you mean "can't prove it," otherwise it doesn't make sense to me. Anyway, creation[ism] doesn't blindly ignore the laws of physics. Anything about science that creationism ignores is done so intentionally. Mostly creationism selects and interprets the data (they even state that they are interpreting the data differently in light of revealed scripture) so that it will fit the proposed creationist scenario. Data that doesn't fit is ignored completely or is interpreted in such a way as to make it seem ridiculous. Generally, creationism interprets each bit of data in isolation, none having any effect on any other. Of course, in science, the fact that physics supports geology (and vice versa), and that they both support and are supported by biology adds to the strength of science.
 
More about this in my "Differences of science and religion" thread.
Been there, done that.
Voldy

The way I see it, the process (NOT THEORY IT IS A PROVEN PROCESS) of evolution is like the line of best fit on a graph.The line represents the process of evolution and the points on the graph represent the facts we have. The line of best thing is the best thing we have; it fits on most of the points and has the right direction even for those points a little ways away from the line. That is what science is; the very best explanation we have for what surrounds us. One day, maybe science will help us explain all that surrounds us! Every day, new scientific discoveries are made, and they bring us one step closer.
Matthew S

If you look at the sheer coindences involved in getting an intellegent human to evolve it is mind Boggling. So many lucky chances at the right moment that on the surface points to some creator.
 
 The sun is just the right distance from the star packed center of the galaxy to provide a stable enviornment, so that the earth is not bombarded but comets and big asteroids all that often. 
 
 The earth is just the right distance from the sun to sustain a stable environment for life.
 
 The earth has a large moon that stabilizes the axis so the climate remains Relatively stable.
 
 
 Juptier attracts most big stuff and helps keep the earth from getting bombarded more often then it does.
 
 The earth has a very large magnetic field to keep most of the solar particals from sterilizing the surface.
 
 
 LIfe is so complex that it is hard to imagine how it came into being without help.
 
 
 I am not trying to argue for or against a creator. Just we are very lucky and very special.
DamEtel

Matthew S: The sun is just the right distance from the star packed center of the galaxy to provide a stable enviornment, so that the earth is not bombarded but comets and big asteroids all that often. 

 
 "Just the right distance" is misleading. How many thousands of light years wide is this "just the right distance from the galactic nucleus" band? And it stretches completely around the galactic nucleus, encircling it, to boot: how many thousands of light years is that?
 
 And would we expect life to exist where it couldn't? No. Of course if we find life in our vast galaxy it would be where life could exist, not where it couldn't. So any life reflecting upon where it is positioned in the galaxy would see itself being within this enormously huge "just the right distance" from the galactic nucleus band: selection effect.
 
 
Matthew S: The earth is just the right distance from the sun to sustain a stable environment for life.

 
 The idea of a narrow Goldilocks zone of orbits for life-sustaining planets has lost much, if not all, of its validity. For example, astrobiologists have started considering the possibility of there being life on one or more of the moons of Jupiter and/or Saturn, and have started ramping up to look for it. Those moons are far outside the original, narrow Goldilocks zone.
 
 
Matthew S: Juptier attracts most big stuff and helps keep the earth from getting bombarded more often then it does.

 
 But the Earth still gets blasted. The last big one I know of off the top of my head was in 1908 in Tunguska, IIRC, which exploded above the ground, luckily in an ESSENTIALLY (i.e., basically, practically, or virtually) uninhabited area.
 
 
Matthew S: The earth has a very large magnetic field to keep most of the solar particals from sterilizing the surface.

 
 Some other planets in our solar system also have very large magnetic fields (magnetospheres).
 
 
Matthew S: LIfe is so complex that it is hard to imagine how it came into being without help.

 
 Don't look at extant life, especially complex metazoans. Many/most OOL scientists consider the first life forms to have been a mere molecule (mere, as compared to a modern eukaryotic cell): a self-sustaining, self-replicating molecule capable of evolving would be the form of life they are interested in.

 If I gave the impression that I thought Matthew S was arguing Creationism - despite his claim - I didn't mean to. I've read a book, entitled "Rare Earth", written by two mainstream NAS scientists, that says most of what Matthew pointed out.

pandion

If I gave the impression that I thought Matthew S was arguing Creationism - despite his claim - I didn't mean to. I've read a book, entitled "Rare Earth", written by two mainstream NAS scientists, that says most of what Matthew pointed out.
But what Matthew S posted was quite characteristic of creationist claptrap. It boils down to "it's all so wonderful that GODMUSTADUNIT" that is so typical of creationists. All of those arguments boil down to so what! Life arose on earth because conditions were right - water, temperature, organic molecules, etc.
 
 Physics, chemistry, geology, and biology is what they is! Next thing is you're going to be telling me that when I threw a curve ball that had batters diving for the ground (strike three!), that somehow GODMUSTADUNIT. (My screwball worked too.)
Iuris

According to Henry Morris of the ICR those craters were caused by the war between the forces of God lead by Michael the archangel against Satan and his demons. 

 
 Now there's an idea: War in Heaven:the movie. 200.000.000,00$ spent on special effects alone. I'd go and see it. Well, probably, if they focused on the action and kept the proselityzing to a minimum...
 
 As for the arument of Earth is so special for us, I'd like to point out that it's perfect for us as we are. It is actually the exact opposite: life has adapted so well to the Earth as it is.
 
 We have little idea of what alternative evolutionary ways life could take. Who knows what a silicone based ecology would look like - and what it would like in a planet. Maybe it would need to be closer to the sun, maybe it would need to be further from it, who knows.

beervolcano

The leading theory as to how the Earth got such a large moon, being a smallish (albeit the largest) rocky planet in the inner solar system is that a Mars-sized planet shared much of the orbit of the early pre-Earth at a LaGrange point. Eventually this unstable orbit decayed and the Mars-sized planet and the pre-Earth collided. For lack of a better term, they melted together and spewed a lot of ejecta into the orbit of the newly formed larger planet. This ejecta coalesced over time into the Moon. At that time, it is estimated that the Moon was much closer the the Earth, so that an earthbound observer would see it rotating, it would have been larger than the sun in the sky, and the day on Earth was a mere 14 hours or so. Over time, the Moon is moving away from the Earth, and this is measured with lasers. One day it will be smaller than the sun in the sky. Right now, it's pretty much exactly the same size as the sun in the sky. There's another cosmic coincidence. The time in geologic history that the Moon is the exact size of the sun in the sky is the same time that there is an species on the Earth intelligent enough to apprectiate the aesthetics of such a conjunction. 
 
 When I first read "what about the moon," I thought there would be a discussion of the stabilization of Earth's rotation given by the Moon, or maybe talk about the tides that may have had something to do with life (or not). Supposedly, without the Moon, the Earth would precess a bit more wildly on its axis. This would result in more dramatic temperature and climate changes in relatively short spans of time that would make life a bit more difficult to come by (supposedly, or any life that survived would be quite rugged indeed).
 
 Talking about "Privileged Planets" and special circumstances surrounding life as being indicators of a supreme intelligence is much like a lottery winner claiming that, since he has won the lottery, he could not have done so by mere chance.
Monster

Looking for someone to provide FACTS about why there is a creator.

 It's simple, we can not know why or why not at this point.
 
 However there are only two choices: 
 
 There is a creator(s) or there is not a creator(s).
 
 All you have to do is pick one (or not).
 
 Hopefully you're not religious.
 
 That way, you can always change your mind later!
birdan

The world around us is full of mysteries that humans can't explain. It is also visted all too often by catastrophe that causes death, pain, and misery to millions of people. 
 
 Societies need rules, ethics, and morals. Societies also need a sense of purpose and direction to maintain cohesion. 
 
 God provides answers and explanations to things people can't understand. God allows people to believe they have some sort of protection from forces they can't control. God provides an external moral code for a society to follow.
 
 Humans, using their intelligence, designed a God to fulfill all the above conditions. So I would have to say I believe that God was intelligently designed. But times have changed since God 1.0, and I think it's time for a new release.
